Main Features
Notes
about notes

ADD

Adding email Recipients
ADD

When and where should I send a new note? 
While the social signals about who can speak up can be complex, Socialroots is
designed to support a new way of listening and participating in groups. Notes
are meant to replace outdated forums and listservs, untangle email threads, and
help people listen to and engage on the things that matter most to them. Here
are some basic guidelines: 

 * Most obviously, start a new note when you have something new to say that does
   not already have an obvious active conversation or project around it. Notes
   are lightweight containers meant to move conversations to action. Does each
   project or topic need a subgroup? Probably not. Use notes, and see what gains
   traction in the group. 
 * When you want to bring a conversation in a different direction, consider
   creating a new note [[add comment about forking / related notes for
   conttext?]] to keep discussions from reverting to 'anything goes'. 
 * When you are not sure if a note needs to be an announcement, ask a co-lead.
   That decision is usually best determined by the group norms - just notice
   how many people you are notifying! Spending attention wisely helps groups be
   more engaged and effective.

See this post for more about collaborative communication
[https://www.socialroots.io/collaborative-communication-basics/] and some basics
of what to consider as you compose a note. 

My Workspace
Your workspace is your place for a quick view of conversations you care about
across all your groups, your group memberships, profile and account information,
and activity and contributions. If any of this space is difficult or confusing
in any way, or if you see how you'd like it changed, [[please let us know]]. 

Inbox
See and filter all the notes you have participated in across groups, prioritized
for you. Scan and assess new action requests and other incoming notes in one
spot. Your inbox has no action you need to take, and aims to streamline your
personal view of activity across all your groups and networks.

posts.html:
Welcome! You can find our full help docs here, but here's a short guide to get you rolling.

3 key things:

  1. Set your notifications:
    Everything is muted by default. Yay! To get email notifications for new activity, you have to change the notification frequency of a note. If you want to get notified of new activity, you can choose either daily or immediate.
  2. Choose whether to notify:
    Whether you notify anyone in the first place is up to you. As you start a conversation, you can choose to email everyone, or leave it in the app only.
  3. See recent notes:
    On a subgroup's dashboard, you can see the last five "Recent Notes". You can also click on "Group Notes" or "Subgroup Notes" in the left navigation of any group or subgroup to see all the notes sent by and to that group or subgroup. The workspace icon in the upper left corner will show you your inbox, with notes across all your groups.

Frequently Asked Questions

What is a note?

A note on Socialroots is a way to say something in a group or subgroup. Everyone in that group or subgroup can see the notes. As you compose a note, you can choose to additionally send an email version to all recipients, or not.

What is a group?

A group is a totally independent / autonomous container for a group of people doing something together. A group can be an organization, a stand alone project, a private workspace, or a team.

When should I create a group vs subgroup?

Subgroups are always managed by a group. So if the work is happening as part of the group, you should create a subgroup. If the work is stand-alone, or if a project needs subgroups of its own, make it a group. For more detail on this see this help docs section.

Who can see what's in groups and subgroups?

Only members of the group or subgroup can see anything in the group. The only things someone outside the group or subgroup can see is the group's About page, as well as any notes to which they were manually added as an email (external) recipient.

How do roles work?

There are 3 roles in each group or subgroup: lead, participant, and supporter.

  • Leads can do anything.
  • Participants can start subgroups and author notes in subgroups.
  • Supporters can reply to notes and join some subgroups.

Have fun! See our docs for more, or ask questions at our help desk in the Socialroots Community.

posts.html:
OTHER BLOGS

The power stick (explicit power + money)

The pace of engagement

(the pace layers of a community)

if the core team (you) are not growing, neither will the community

graphic:

Audience - email CRM / everyone in a space you can speak to with authority (gets all the attention)

Passive interest (reading / sharing) - informed community

Active interest (replying/ posting response) - consultative community

Clients and customers (hires you for a JTBD)

paying supporters (believe in your ongoing value creation) - patron / member community

paying members (believe in the above AND want to connect / collaborate with each other.)

project (emergent) teams - not only there to network, but to DO the work. Be sure to create the ability to allocate resources out to avoid participation imbalances. Pay members who cannot join projects for free.

core (admin) teams - do and coordinate work - allocation of resources is usually here. push as much of the coordination function into project groups or cross-group habits as possible

Working with the layers

Start with the center

First: Community starts with a healthy team.Whether your team is small, large, or made up of several teams, get honest. [add a little of the stuff to do] Dig deeper and learn five practical steps we recommend to nurture team health here.

Even if you are a solo-preneur, start a monthly call with your biggest fans, or others in your position. Step outside of your brand and your comfort zone and find connections you did not expect. Do hard work, together.

CONWAY's LAW

Exhaust is not exhausting

Next: find passive feedback - attention is a big ask. look for exhaust.

Next: Do meaningful things. Bring value, respect serendipity, don't have to see the A to B link between helping others and building your brand. A healthy community helps each other. If you don't reach out, you'll likely find yourself nurturing a community of grifters looking for an angle.

What trash is your treasure?

Compost is nutrients

POWER

Next: Clarify and hold boundaries - (ie - the zebra dazzle saying 'we have too much right now') We are, even together, only human.

Next: Connect people with resources - where are the boundaries? Those are the places you might want hire help. Ask people what they are struggling with, and look for any way to see passive struggle. the 'engaged' and the very online give only a skewed sample of people's perspective on your work. cite https://www.nngroup.com/articles/participation-inequality/

be sure that the allocation and announcement of available resources fights participation inequality some how - get resources to the folks on the outer bounds as well as the core / active folks

on flocking

If you know exactly what needs to exist, say, a paperclip, the system to make that very scoped and specific thing will need some very complicated rules and structures. A paperclip factory. However, the magic of networks rests in emergence. You don't have a spec for the result, and the surprising and serendipitous behavior that emerges can't be created with a factory mindset. You need just a few simple rules to guide this complexity. A flock of starlings doesn't need complicated rules. Each bird does 3 things: tries not to crash, stays close to the few birds around them, and matches the direction and velocity of their neighboring birds. Networks can help people coordinate too.

posts.html:
TLDR:

ADD SECTION

As the birdsite burns, it's ripping networks apart. People flee to various other places, or won't leave. Either way, they lose each other. It's a heartbreaking disintegration of a public square for some. Others cackle and celebrate on the sidelines as the "hellsite" self-destructs. Many see this moment as an opportunity for definition and adoption of more democratically-run technologies.

But underneath the clouded drama of the day, there's a silver lining. Suddenly, literacy and learning surge about the decentralized web, peer-to-peer "fediverse", cooperative ownership, and things healthy social networks might actually need. Longstanding efforts towards tech built out-of-the-box to support democratic principles sees a huge influx of new interest. The importance of ownership structures looms into view for those who may never have given a thought to control of their data.

I've been exploring the technologies as an ecologist since stumbling into the 2018 Decentralized Web Summit. I made an early map of the landscape there. I co-founded a coop to share learning and build literacy about more trustworthy technologies. One ongoing and interesting conversation is the call to 'separate the data from the app'. In many conversations, this comes down to a binary:

Platforms vs Protocols

In the web3 / dweb / federated tech-head conversations, platforms are, indeed, lava. Touch the topic on the platform side and it will burn you. Protocols are all the rage. And there's many good reasons for that.

  • to fractal rather than fracture, people protocols are needed: see https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2022/11/fediverse-could-be-awesome-if-we-dont-screw-it

see graphic here https://medium.com/bosonprotocol/pipelines-to-platforms-to-protocols-reconfiguring-value-and-redesigning-markets-548b1fffc84

since 2015...

since 2019...

Omidyar

Prosocial

Ostrom Workshop

MetaGov

DWeb

Amy E

NRhythm

symbiotic relationships between humans and machines, and between human / machine stacks

I concluded that PKM is bullshit only when it is technology-centric, and not a set of processes, individually constructed, to help each of us make sense of our world and work more effectively.

See Jarche on open protocols connect small pieces loosely joined

For another post

  • humanity has a new communication infrastructure.
  • web one had a peer-to-peer vision
  • web two is killing us
  • web three is killing itself, but also decentralization is a huge part of the answer

posts.html:
Prior to social media, the activities of organizing a group of people toward a shared goal largely took place in living rooms and offices, connected during times of campaigning via the switchboard operations of home phone lines.

With widescale adoption of social mobile and web apps, and particularly since the remote-working boom brought about by the Coronavirus pandemic, even the most local, direct action groups are looking to ICTs Information & Communication Technologies to aid and enhance their work of coordination, cooperation and collaboration.

-> Could demonstrate with the study on the Farmer's Movement in India

The vast market of software services offering an improvement to workflow or an alternative to billionaire-owned social media platforms can feel pretty overwhelming.

What's a zap? Which slack channel should host this conversation? How do we include that active member who refuses to use Facebook?

The economic influences which the internet has grown up within have shaped the way we "the users" think about our tools. Microsoft's Office Suite puts barbed wire fences around all our work. Facebook demand higher and higher payments to boost your post to your audience.

But these experiences and business models limit the ways our communities can imagine participation.

Good idea, I'll make a Facebook group

Often, groups with a shared mission or purpose end up adopting whatever ICTs most of the members already use, without a design consideration about whether its functions are appropriate ways to service the work.

This is to be anticipated - those with the capital pour millions of dollars into designing 'frictionless onboarding' and pursuing ways to trap their 'users' in the corporation's territory, whether through declaring ownership over your data or throwing their hoarded resources into outcompeting underdog software.

If you have already 'friended' all the members in one place, what's easier than using that same place to form your group?

But should it be so easy to give away our sovereignty, and simply accept the design choices (and biases) of this corporation over our own better judgement about what kind of container will help us work well together?

If your group is considering how you can use the internet in better ways, it's helpful to think about needs and, if you have capacity, about the longterm societal repercussions.

Sam Hahn introduces the idea of artifacts in the Knowledge Federation Journal (KFJournal.

The article suggests nine distinct ICT functions, that may or may not be hosted in cyberspace. This poses a question:

With so many apps servicing different functions, should our group look for one app that serves all our activities, or does every member need nine different logins and bookmarks in order to track all the activity?

Actually, it would be ridiculous to consider that either extreme would be a good idea.

A tool which tries to do everything can become too complex and confusing to navigate. Whereas the friction of joining any new service is not to be underestimated.

It's not reasonable to expect your community members to navigate an overwhelming diversity of interfaces and domains.

Imagine if, instead, we could select a handful of services which interoperated smoothly between each other?
Even better, what if the data we shared with our group was synced between us, but each member could choose our own interface to access and navigate each conversation or document?

The Human Interface Project (hi:project) advocates a participation with technology which better reflects each person's needs and choices over the layout prescribed by the design team who provide the technological service.

Solving wicked problems together

Here at Socialroots, we are keeping our eye on these emerging patterns while building an innovative technology for group and cross-group exchanges.

As a cooperative, we align with the aims of the Fediverse, and seek to implement standards which provide the kind of interoperability that will lead to an internet where communities choose what to do with their data, rather than locking it into our territory.

We are also building our default UI (User Interface) to acknowledge and hold space for the recurring challenges of groups wanting to coordinate across a membership who may have different levels of digital literacy, preferences, commitments and roles within the organisation, as well as time to spend engaging.

On our dashboard, the Key Links section provides a home to redirect members to each online activity space regardless where they may be hosted a google doc with your code of conduct, a task tracking tool, a video conferencing link, etc.

We are also emphasizing Notes as conversation containers which mimic the flexibility of real world organizing; supporting opt-in participation to the platform without excluding those conversation participants who would rather stay in their email inbox.

Each subgroup reflects a particular audience for your conversations, and with cross-group addressing we are able to launch conversations in the intersections of group boundaries, to coordinate more succinctly with "that subset of that partnering organisation", or "the members of that movement who are in our region".

We aren't trying to do it all.

Growing in the (unwalled) app-garden of the Fediverse, our different needs or functions may be met with a service like Nextcloud for collaborative document creation and management, Corteza for operations, workflow & CRM, Mastodon for social media, and Mobilizon for event management.

Beyond the ActivityPub protocol (standards which allow projects of the Fediverse to speak with each other), our team might run a Signal group chat for rapid open conversation, or Sticky Studio to whiteboard our ideas and run strategy sessions.

Because of interoperable protocols, it is possible that we don't need to travel to a new domain or create a unique login for access to these services. The way we can create an account with one-click using our Google or Apple account, we can imagine navigating between apps with an OpenID linked to our home account.

It may feel like there are many apps, brands, and services to solve any conceivable problem.
By focusing on the patterns of functionality and opting for cooperative technologies, your groups' needs can be met in a way that reduces dependency on extractive corporations, without sacrificing quality and performance.

When exploring the options and alternatives, consider the 'ecosystem' that is growing in your garden, and follow the philosophy of companion planting.

Asking how two tools might interact with each other means that over time you will greatly reduce the cost of maintenance or reliance on artificial fixes.

The future of Socialroots will include developing our RESTful API & launching an SDK, so developers can write custom functionality, providing any number of ways to link in with your home base.

And we will continue to follow decentralized web standards and fair governance practices, so that our platform grows around the emerging needs and opportunities of the people who choose to make Socialroots their group home.

Although we are still young, we are building closely with our early user communities to ensure our roadmap meets current needs while setting our compass toward a fair, open, modular and humane internet.

-> Is there a call to action to end with? Sign up for the waiting list?

posts.html:
Imagine a giant fundraising thermometer collecting donations to reach the goal for the good of a community.

If Socialroots is to become a critical piece of public infrastructure for a complex, changing world, we have a few dangers to avoid or confront.

Open Source poses threats to a co-operative.

  • What is cooperative source
  • Building closely with the people doing ecosocial work
  • Applying prosocial insights & science to our internal structure & systems.

posts.html:
Socialroots, the flagship product of Wicked Coop, is seeking a remote Full Stack Web Application Developer.

About Socialroots

Wicked Co-op LCA is an innovative cooperative software organization in early stages of development and the first co-op to win the Phase II Small Business Innovation Grant from the National Science Foundation. We are building the Socialroots platform for more efficient decentralized coordination.

Decentralized coordination is the problem of our time. Everything from climate change to social change to innovation is fundamentally a problem of large scale, efficient decentralized coordination. By building a platform that decreases the cost of cross-disciplinary coordination, we hope to connect the social network of productivity to increase the rate of innovation and systemic change.

About the role

As a full-stack developer on our team, you will work across both front-end and back-end tasks, typically with a focus on one or the other but with knowledge of both.

The developer will be architecting and implementing new features, as well as enhancing existing function and assisting the engineering team in refining the existing platform for reliability, robustness, and scale.

Required skills:

  • Proficiency in modern (ES6) Javascript, with experience using NodeJS.
  • Proficiency with modern CSS frameworks.
  • Proficiency with SQL and experience writing structured queries.
  • Proficiency with backend or application programming languages such as C/C++, Java, Erlang/Elixir, Rust, Golang, Ruby on Rails, Python/Flask, or PHP/Laravel.
  • Understanding of modern application development architectures such as AWS, Azure, Google Cloud, or other cloud deployment platforms.
  • Experience working with an Agile organization.

Bonus skills:

  • Experience building web applications in ReactJS with Apollo client.
  • Experience with Tailwinds CSS.
  • Experience with GraphQL API design and implementation.
  • Experience with microservice design and implementation using Golang.
  • Experience with TDD/BDD using Cucumber/Gherkin and CypressJS.


Reach us via team@socialroots.io if you have questions or are ready to apply.

posts.html:
Grounded in evolutionary science, and aiming to enhance cooperation and inspire positive change for the well-being of others, we invite you to explore the world through the lens of prosocial. A worldview, attitude, practice, and more,

About

Learning resources

Find out more: website.

Template example:

Zebras Unite helps aligned founders connect with each other, with investors, and better discover, catalyze, and create resources together. As we cooperate, we help strengthen our movement for a new approach to startups. If you suspect you are also a zebra, we invite you to join us as a co-op member. Many people are building businesses that are better for the world. You don't need to do it alone.

REPLACE IMAGE

About Zebras Unite

It started as a movement catalyzed by the flood of responses to a post from the four Zebra co-founders, and became a manifesto: Zebras Fix What Unicorns Break. Now, Zebras Unite has grown into a brand stewarded by a non-profit, and a member-owned for-profit co-operative. Projects, partnerships, podcasts, buzz, blogs, and businesses of all sorts can be found bubbling up around the movement.

Learning Resources

Socialroots is proud to part of the dazzle (the collective noun for zebras) and an early member of this new co-operative. We encourage you to check out Zebras, and to join the movement. Here are a couple of learning resources we found valuable.

  • Discover how embedding cooperative mutualistic principles can make business more efficient, with Zebras Unite founder Mara Zepeda in conversation on the Brave New Work podcast:
  • Learn what co-operating with Zebras is all about, from the incredible Kate "Sassy" Sassoon, the Zebras Unite Co-operative Director of Membership:
Join Zebras Unite

posts.html:
key points

  • the strength of a network is in its ability to support leadership from a diverse range of people
  • growing support for leaderful ways of working together, in contrast to leaderless approaches.
  • sharing power reduces burnout & bottlenecks, enables innovation, dignity and effectiveness
  • a few good tools to encourage sharing of leadership:
  • full circle leadership
  • focusing on roles and domains when collaborating
  • decision-making tree to push decisions to the edges
  • ?
  • quotes from our event:
  • 16:52 or 17:10 18:26 Carol speaks about power & trusting that everyone can lead
  • 27:09 28:58 Jay points out that burnout is a structural issue

takeaways

  • common organizational management tools arent so flexible for a network which encourages leadership emerging from the edges
  • support the people in your network who have the energy to take responsibility
  • Socialroots makes your whole network more awesome with our fractals of permission layers

message

  • research and expertize suggests that networks thrive when leadership is shared, and open to step into. however, not all management tools support this paradigm. Socialroots does. So do some of these useful practices which we dug up so you can make a difference straight away.

tone

  • genuinely invested in the capacity of healthy networks, and want to encourage/guide network coordinators to implement practices that will help them success.

background material (facts to include)

Clip of Carol talking about power

https://www.researchgate.net/publication/291659151_Preparing_for_leaderful_practice

posts.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[],"markups":[["a",["href","https://www.eventbrite.com/e/engagement-clears-the-way-supporting-your-network-without-bottlenecking-tickets-526922197477"]],["a",["href","https://undefined/"]],["a",["href","https://www.startercultures.us/creative-offerings/communication-dojo"]],["a",["href","https://www.presentofwork.com/"]],["strong"],["a",["href","https://www.cnvc.org/learn-nvc/what-is-nvc"]],["a",["href","https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T-groups"]],["a",["href","https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bohm_Dialogue"]],["a",["href","https://www.circlingeurope.com/what-is-circling"]],["a",["href","https://book.collectivepresencing.org/"]],["a",["href","https://www.eventbrite.com/cc/network-coordination-refining-your-skills-1687489"]],["a",["href","/signup/"]]],"sections":[[1,"h3",[[0,[],0,"Key points:"]]],[3,"ul",[[[0,[],0,"Communication strategy can bottleneck everything else you want to do"]],[[0,[],0,"Contexts are shifting the ways we communicate - posts.html:
Key points:

  • Communication strategy can bottleneck everything else you want to do
  • Contexts are shifting the ways we communicate - internet both as medium & consequences of bridging across culture like never before
  • Creating new structures to respond to the challenges of our time requires adapting our habits of speech and behaviour.
  • Learning networks support widespread adaptation and selection of practices while giving members of the network a chance to actually practice and integrate what is being learned.
  • To get better at something, its important to have a space where its safe to do something different, and where we can welcome the opportunity of having our mistakes or unsupportive habits reflected back to us

Takeaways:

  • People in our community are doing awesome stuff
  • People who are experts in network + community building endorse Socialroots (because)
  • Socialroots helps you excel at the stuff that can otherwise grow really tricky, really fast.
  • Check out our newsletters for future events that help you get better at network coordination.

Message:

  • If youre considering Socialroots, chances are you communicate with a lot of different people all the time. We want you to be awesome at that work. A speaker at our recent panel runs Communication Dojos, which you might like to get involved with. Practicing skillful communication is a perfect complement to adopting a network-literate technology; these two things can greatly expand whats possible for your network, through you.

Tone:

  1. celebrating Carol and the Present of Work.
  2. bridging / sharing insights about skillful leadership and communication habits.
  3. establishing some depth of the research that socialroots is being built with

Background material:

The Feb event page: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/engagement-clears-the-way-supporting-your-network-without-bottlenecking-tickets-526922197477

Our presenter Carol Xu referenced the practices of the Communication Dojo and her consultancy Present of Work that helps empower leaders to co-create cultures of trust, alignment, and authenticity.

She also mentioned a few conversation practices including:

  • Non-violent communication
  • T-group
  • Bohm dialogue
  • Circling
  • Collective presencing

Calls to action:

Keep an eye out for our upcoming events: https://www.eventbrite.com/cc/network-coordination-refining-your-skills-1687489 or subscribe to our newsletter

Sign up for early access: https://www.socialroots.io/signup/

posts.html:
key points

  • shared goals can become difficult as a network expands to envelop various niche and local use cases
  • the goal you might have as a network coordinator should be focused on the impact that you are creating together, and ways to enable that happening
  • tools you can use: theory of change, sociocratic approach to separating policy and process decisions, storytelling which grounds us in the visceral experience of what success might look, feel, smell, taste, or sound like.
  • definition of success can include personal definitions - embrace plurality.

takeaways

  • support goals to continue changing. socialroots does this with current focus, enabling a quick way to stay informed about the changes across the different components of your network.
  • encourage your members to stay active by centering their goals, their definition of success, their role in contributing to making the larger thing happen while feeling supported to meet their personal goals. having members share stories with each other to highlight whats working, get feedback, new inspiration, and build connections all at once.

message

tone

background material

Quote from Lauren: When leadership is coherent, I get the sensation of being a part of a developing wave. When the wave is headed in the right direction, leadership is really just facilitating, supporting, guiding and letting the wave do its thing. What it viscerally feels like.

https://complexity.simplecast.com/episodes/101-j7hP_Sf5

Ambiguous coherence - pluralistic set of inchoate goals - large scale collective organisation.

Metaphysics of ambiguity - policy vs protocol, goals with variety of ways to measure & value.

Get a clip from this perspective

Q: When you get a really engaged network, what signals that you may see (especially early) are warning signs? Before disengagement - what actions can a catalyst take which address some of these concerns? Adjustments to shift the system early?

Lauren: So many of the metrics typically used to measure engagement (maybe outside the world of network weaving) are not sensitive enough to sense the early stages of a disengaged group. What that means for network coordinators is, they cant pay that much attention to time spent in digital spaces, number of logins, surveys and so on. They need to be in touch with the network itself and sensing it in a variety of other ways.

For me, the indicator, 2 or 3-fold people losing a sense that they can contribute meaningfully. Subtle at first. See people giving away a task, or stepping away from something they previously would have stepped into. Reduced sense of commitment to the purpose of the org, maybe it has shifted or their purpose has shifted.

Less of a sense of belonging. Subtle an relational things - what Carol said about communication - sense in the context. Im trained as a facilitator and quite a hyper-vigilant person so Im always trying to sense it you can feel when somethings wrong.

Jay: I like to talk about smelling it! +1 to hypersensitive, hypervigilant people. Can be a superpower right?

I have a list of things I often point out to my clients. Engagement is so much more full spectrum to how digital marketers use it. I relate a lot of these to human inter-personal dynamics, a reference that a lot of us have.

If youre at a party, what are the signs that everyones bored and going to leave?

  • Everyones doing the same thing. We want to see the full spectrum of engagement. Just arriving, host is introducing people, someone wanting to host a party just like this tomorrow.
  • Engagement ladder, ew, Im disabled, Im not climbing a ladder for you.
  • Weird if everyone is sitting around doing the same thing
  • If everyone looks the same
  • Silo-ing - when one hand doesnt know what the other ones doing.
  • Lack of sharing or training strategies.
  • Do the problem solving and business in public - lack of that, or behind closed doors.
  • People scared to show it for whatever reason.
  • Lack of movement on problems
  • We dont have anyone to do this thing - then it just sits there.
  • New people leaving
  • Digital marketing can teach us some good things - lower the bounce rate. Keep an eye on that initial, how are we pulling people into this journey weve created?
  • Lack of social events and hanging out!
  • The stuff also happens in non-business hangouts.
  • Lack of cross-talk, joking, hanging out thats easy to see.

Carol: burnout is a sign. If youre one of the core organizers and you start noticing, sigh, why do I have to do this? Early sign - its not an individual problem. You might not be the martyr who has to do it all, the problem is systemic.

Lauren: The lack of meaningful conflict. When people dont care enough to bring their issues to the table, its a problem.

We never intended for M4C to be a long term project. During our happy things meetings, open zoom at same time each day where people would pop-in and share. When that began to dwindle, we recognized people had done their work and ready to go, sense the mood and needs of group. We were ready for the closing to come, knew it would be quick.

Carol: Relational, meaningful conflict. I didnt get education or training about, however now there are so many tools and methodologies of communication to help people surface conflict in skillful ways. Sometimes people only have a piece of the picture. Might be afraid if they voice something thats bothering them, it may not be coherent. The sooner you can encourage people to surface those things, the sooner you can put the big picture together. May feel sharp, risk creating harm in the relationship. Frameworks and approaches that people can practice, to have meaningful conflict that deepends relational fabric.

Carol designs and hosts social spaces and innovative "sandboxes" that integrate contemplative, creative, and strategic elements into learning for organizational leaders, community stewards, and purpose-driven individuals. Carol holds a Ph.D. in Management Science and Engineering from Stanford University. She loves going on (in-person, virtual or metaphorical) hikes with people from all walks of life."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[19,3],2,"Jay Carmona"],[0,[],0," has worked on dozens of campaigns since 2008 in a career spanning multiple arenas of the American Left, including labor organizing, environmental justice, LGBT civil rights, faith-based work, and media justice. Before helping to roll out the worlds first campaigns to divest public pension funds from fossil fuels at 350.org, they were instrumental in coordinating major mobilizations in Washington DC. Theyve worked for two City Governments and on the Stop Rush campaign while working at Media Matters for America. Jay specializes in bringing together unlikely partners with a holistic approach to campaigning that includes a seamless blend of both online and offline grassroots organizing."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"At the recently-founded consultancy, Sematonic Strategies, Jay supports creating decentralized, tech-supported community organizing networks and mediagenic online campaigns."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[20,3],2,"Lauren Hebert"],[0,[],0," is a strategist, designer, and facilitator with an integrated understanding of complex adaptive systems, design thinking, sense-making, and human development."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Over the past eight years, Lauren has been designing and leading sense-making processes that activate meaningful collaboration. She has worked with organizations across the spectrumfrom startups to citiesas they address systemic challenges with functional, holistic solutions."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Among her many roles, Lauren was a lead organizer of Make4Covid, a Colorado based crisis response organization that grew to over 2000 members in just a few weeks and provided free PPE to medical professional across the state."]]]]}
posts.html:
This is Part One of our series on network coordination. See also Part Two on building capacity as networks scale and grow.

On February 15th, 2023, Socialroots convened a panel on network engagement with three extraordinary people who have helped us along our path. The event recording below contains a wealth of wisdom from our panelists' experiences.

In this post, we reflect on some core topics and share our insights for refining practices of healthy, skillful coordination.

Signs of network engagement

What does an engaged, mutually-supportive network look and feel like? Here are some key indicators:

  • You'll see plenty of excitement or motivation and rapid growth,
  • The network communicates a clear sense of shared problems and shared purpose,
  • People will be working out loud, supporting a peer-to-peer culture of leadership.

The first two points may seem self-evident. Sensing if there's energy and excitement is a basic human social skill, though it's all too easy to forget 'first principles' when we're under stress. Plenty of resources exist to address the challenge of creating a common agenda for collective impact, a 'minimum common ground' as Aldo De Moor puts it. But we might not naturally sense the third indicator (working out loud). How can we tell if our network is fostering healthy interactions? As network coordinators, we need to learn to listen for silence. We need to model the transparency we wish to cultivate. Beyond this, working out loud requires people to change habits, to take risks, to be willing to share drafts and avoid perfection. This behavior flies in the face of the old adage, 'knowledge is power', and asks for an openness we are not all accustomed to.

But today, learning is power. The capacity to adapt is critical for our time. By cultivating habits of working out loud (through promoting psychological safety and demonstrating vulnerability), we tighten the feedback loops required for rapid learning and adaptation. It also encourages a relational, rather than transactional, approach. It requires us to both step into and cede positions of leadership as our focus changes. It builds flexibility and trust. This 'new' way of networked working is actually very human - as Carol pointed out, we need to learn from ancient wisdom and recognize that building our networks in this way is new only in the sense that its different from the current dominant paradigm.

Start by trusting that everybody can lead. Everybody has the ability to see whats needed at different points in time.

-Carol Xu

Unavoidable Bottlenecks

Why do network coordinators so often end up in a bottleneck position?

  • Network and community coordination involves curation. This is a service provided by the most involved, active people to other members.
  • Sometimes, especially early on, bottlenecks are useful for that curation, or to slow down in order to make better decisions together.
  • BUT bottlenecks are not an individual behavior, they are a systemic structure, and so can be very hard to shift once set up.

We've heard a lot in our research about the position of bottlenecks and the desire to escape that dynamic. But bottlenecks will appear in most if not all networks. We can minimize them, and build around them, but we cannot avoid them entirely. Anytime information asymmetry exists, it will create either power imbalances (if information is hoarded) or bottleneck positions (as we strive to share information) without mature distributed organizing structures in place.

Rather than fight or deny these positions, we need to recognize them as a common structural phase in networks. Then we can move from that hub-and-spoke phase into sharing power. We can do this by encouraging the small group formation which helps shift the flow of information and trust into a more appropriately distributed structure. By paying attention to the systems that emerge from how we work together, we gain the ability to choose better patterns.

We needed to slow things down intentionally sometimes. We were moving at such a pace, with so many people, that the bottleneck was intentionally created to make sure we could make decisions about effectiveness and safety.... Then as we wanted to move faster, as the context changed, we found those bottlenecks got in the way.

-Lauren Hebert

Clearing the way

How can we escape the dangers of bottlenecks?

  • Make sure that those in central positions are aware of the bottleneck traps.
  • Encourage new voices to reduce establishing invisible bias (we've all got it!).
  • Invite people into co-leadership, learning and use double linking whenever you can.

Power is a drug. The bottleneck position comes with headaches and busywork, but it also comes with power. One of the things that emerged in this conversation was the need for awareness, by anyone stepping into leadership, of the traps we can too easily fall into when we hold positions of power. Coordinators must remain aware of the fragility and danger to the existence of the network that condensing power brings. If that stays top of mind, they continually practice giving power to others.

Ways our panel discussed to encourage this habit include double-linking, co-leadership, and patterns of learning and mentoring. Not only do these help with the bottleneck problem, you get faster, better decisions when people work and learn together regularly. When successful, power expands; the network, rather than a single individual, gains the power to thrive. These conditions can create abundance for far more people than otherwise would be available.

Bottlenecking is a system. That means its less of an individual issue or failing of humans, and more about how we set up our orientation to the work, how we structure working groups and the way we approach leadership in organizations. Only a system can help fix the system.

-Jay Carmona

Warning signs

What signals or early warning signs hint at disengagement, and what actions can coordinators take to address this?

  • People start to lose a sense that they can jump in and contribute meaningfully.
  • Look for what's not there - things missing, or things all the same.
  • Beware of metrics typically used to measure 'engagement'. They are not sensitive enough to sense the early stages of a disengaged group.

We love (LOVE!) Jay's party analogies. Too often, studying relational dynamics draw us into draws us into densely theoretical or heavy-handed efforts to create connections. Jay reminds us that engagement - or sensing the lack of - is something we humans do very naturally. Whether wallflowers, dancers, DJs, hosts, or cooks, we're all social animals. If we tune into the feeling of a crowd in this most human way, we can listen, feel, smell, and otherwise sense the vibe in the room. Networks change; ebbs and flows are natural. To identify the dangers of disengagement early, look for what's not there. You may see a lack of working out loud, new people not joining or sticking around, people who all look or sound the same, stalled progress or people claiming actions, lack of variety, or even a lack of meaningful conflict.

To convene a healthy network of humans, as with any fun party, hosts need to be - or become - sensitive and kind enough to see, address, and shift things like confusion, sadness, loneliness, fear. Be careful that you arent suppressing this valuable feedback. You might proactively create ways to surface these indicators. Tune into, or perhaps even invite 'meaningful conflict'. People who care enough to disagree well can shape something that has purpose. Conveners need to be frank with themselves and their active members when they sense disengagement. They also need to be brave enough to do something about it, or the network will fizzle out. Once people start walking out the door, it's likely too late to do anything to restart the party.

If youre at a party, what are the signs that people are bored and going to leave? ...If everyone was sitting with a drink and staring back at me - or, if everyone looks the same or acts the same - that's weird right? My hair would stand up because it's not a normal human situation. The same thing applies in digital communities.

-Jay Carmona

Healthy networked leadership

When people co-create a healthy network, what does leadership look like? How can you prevent re-centralizing but lead enough to help the coordination?

  • Hierarchical structures have their own merits (nature is full of nested hierarchies) but people in central roles must also be aware of the traps. Centralizing power creates fragility, and unrestrained hierarchies can cause problems analogous to cancer.
  • Look for leaders willing to intentionally teach what they do, so that two people can now do that thing. This pairs well with co-leadership.
  • Keep power explicit, but realize that healthy networked leadership structures are dynamic. Regularly check in with new members to understanding the experience of getting oriented in a changing environment.

For healthy and effective networks to thrive, co-leadership is key. Too often, when people try to build an equitable network, they want to share power with everyone. This leads to a lack of clarity, even chaos, where nothing gets done. In many networks, even if progress is made, too few people get credit. Work can be invisible; or worse, credit claimed when unearned. Success goes not only to the successful, but those willing to make themselves visible. The power of networks can have a dark underbelly where the conveners or known figures get all the acclaim, whether sought or not.

Sharing power helps avoid these dark patterns. This does not mean a completely flat structure; it can start with partnering with one person. Ask a board member or CEO to mentor someone. Step into partnership with active community members early and often. A model of co-leadership, as described above, can help this happen. As you introduce co-leadership, be sure to pay attention to perspectives from both the core team and the wider community. Do people with power in the network recognize the traps? Do they help each other stay out of ruts and build habits of offering power to others? Do community members have easy ways to give feedback about what's not working well for them? Are they clear how to deepen their involvement? Can they trust that their work will be recognized and valued? When "Yes!" is the answer to these kinds of questions, networks find their tune, and play 'in concert', like an orchestra being guided by the conductor and the sheet music.

If Im a leader at the top of a hierarchy or bottleneck...[I need to notice if] for example, people stop talking to me, or people are afraid of bringing up real tensions. [If so], my power and habits are getting in the way. In some ways, the end result [of paying attention to those dynamics] is decentralizing power or making it explicit.

-Carol Xu

Want to apply or suggest a network for early access to Socialroots? Purpose-built for networked organizations, we help coordinators reduce bottlenecks, de-silo, and more easily show the impact of their networks to stakeholders.

Suggest a network >

Network discovery

Shout outs to a few of our friends in attendance

During this event we were glad to see a few folks arrive whose work has informed what we are building at Socialroots. We'll add some links here so their brilliance becomes familiar to you, too!

Aldo De Moor of Community Sense was one of the first people we asked to join us as an advisor member of our cooperative. Expert in community informatics, Aldo introduced the CommunitySensor methodology that takes a cyclical approach to Participatory Community Mapping. He's worked with communities from Africa to British Columbia. You can find his rich research publications here.

Ana Rosa de Lima is one of the most inspiring network coordinators we've met. She's catalyzing a network using bees and the rain forest to help preserve and regenerate each other, all while helping humans find balance in the Amazonian ecosystems. Want to find out more? See the Meli Bees Network, and even get nerdy reading "Do you know about the diversity of bees?".

Daniel Stid, previously at the Hewlett Foundation and steward of the amazing Madison Initiative System Map of Congress. Daniel is currently the executive director of Lyceum Labs, and has some very useful questions for all network weavers to consider in his recent blog post, Non-profit Physician, Heal Thyself!

Event Details

VIDEO: Engagement Clears the Way

(1 hr 7 min)

What makes vibrant networks come alive?

Is your community new, stalled in progress, or struggling with engagement? Is your capacity feeling stretched? Would you like some ideas for encouraging your members to better support each other, and strengthen the network as a whole?

Listen in to a conversation with the founder of pandemic pop-up Make4Covid, Lauren Hebert, community experience designer Carol Xu, and Jay Carmona, labor and activist movements maven. Knowledge ecologist Christina Bowen of Socialroots explores these and other questions of community engagement with the panel.

The first part of a series on network coordination, this panel explores how to ENGAGE your network. Keep in the loop for events focusing on ways to BUILD and GROUND healthy networks: sign up for our newsletter here.

About the panelists

Jia (Carol) Xu, Ph.D, a former researcher of management science, has always been fascinated with new ways of organizing people and resources (such as self-organizing, Decentralized Autonomous Organization, sociocracy, Deliberately Developmental Organization) that empower creativity, resilience, and transparency. Carol designs and hosts social spaces and innovative "sandboxes" that integrate contemplative, creative, and strategic elements into learning for organizational leaders, community stewards, and purpose-driven individuals. Carol holds a Ph.D. in Management Science and Engineering from Stanford University. She loves going on (in-person, virtual or metaphorical) hikes with people from all walks of life.

Jay Carmona has worked on dozens of campaigns since 2008 in a career spanning multiple arenas of the American Left, including labor organizing, environmental justice, LGBT civil rights, faith-based work, and media justice. Before helping to roll out the worlds first campaigns to divest public pension funds from fossil fuels at 350.org, they were instrumental in coordinating major mobilizations in Washington DC. Theyve worked for two City Governments and on the Stop Rush campaign while working at Media Matters for America. Jay specializes in bringing together unlikely partners with a holistic approach to campaigning that includes a seamless blend of both online and offline grassroots organizing.

At the recently-founded consultancy, Sematonic Strategies, Jay supports creating decentralized, tech-supported community organizing networks and mediagenic online campaigns.

Lauren Hebert is a strategist, designer, and facilitator with an integrated understanding of complex adaptive systems, design thinking, sense-making, and human development.

Over the past eight years, Lauren has been designing and leading sense-making processes that activate meaningful collaboration. She has worked with organizations across the spectrumfrom startups to citiesas they address systemic challenges with functional, holistic solutions.

Among her many roles, Lauren was a lead organizer of Make4Covid, a Colorado based crisis response organization that grew to over 2000 members in just a few weeks and provided free PPE to medical professional across the state.
posts.plaintext:
This is Part One of our series on network coordination. See also Part Two
[/build-capacity-scaling-your-network-without-burning-out/] on building capacity
as networks scale and grow.

On February 15th, 2023, Socialroots convened a panel on network engagement with
three extraordinary people who have helped us along our path. The event
recording below
[/clear-the-way-engaging-your-network-without-burning-out/#video-engagement-clears-the-way] 
contains a wealth of wisdom from our panelists' experiences. 

In this post, we reflect on some core topics and share our insights for refining
practices of healthy, skillful coordination.

Signs of network engagement
What does an engaged, mutually-supportive network look and feel like? Here are
some key indicators:

 * You'll see plenty of excitement or motivation and rapid growth, 
 * The network communicates a clear sense of shared problems and shared purpose,
 * People will be working out loud, supporting a peer-to-peer culture of
   leadership.

The first two points may seem self-evident. Sensing if there's energy and
excitement is a basic human social skill, though it's all too easy to forget
'first principles' when we're under stress. Plenty of resources exist to address
the challenge of creating a common agenda
[https://www.fsg.org/resource/collaborating-create-common-agenda/] for
collective impact, a 'minimum common ground' as Aldo De Moor
[https://www.communitysense.nl/about-2/] puts it. But we might not naturally
sense the third indicator (working out loud). How can we tell if our network is
fostering healthy interactions? As network coordinators, we need to learn to
listen for silence. We need to model the transparency we wish to cultivate.
Beyond this, working out loud requires people to change habits, to take risks,
to be willing to share drafts and avoid perfection. This behavior flies in the
face of the old adage, 'knowledge is power', and asks for an openness we are not
all accustomed to. 

But today, learning is power. The capacity to adapt is critical for our time. By
cultivating habits of working out loud (through promoting psychological safety
and demonstrating vulnerability), we tighten the feedback loops required for
rapid learning and adaptation. It also encourages a relational, rather than
transactional, approach. It requires us to both step into and cede positions of
leadership as our focus changes. It builds flexibility and trust. This 'new' way
of networked working is actually very human - as Carol pointed out, we need to
learn from ancient wisdom and recognize that building our networks in this way
is new only in the sense that its different from the current dominant paradigm.

This community engagement continuum shows further details about moving from
outreach to shared leadership. From Principles of Community Engagement
[https://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/communityengagement/community-engagement-continuum.html]> 
Start by trusting that everybody can lead. Everybody has the ability to see
whats needed at different points in time.

-Carol Xu
Unavoidable Bottlenecks
Why do network coordinators so often end up in a bottleneck position? 

 * Network and community coordination involves curation. This is a service
   provided by the most involved, active people to other members.
 * Sometimes, especially early on, bottlenecks are useful for that curation, or
   to slow down in order to make better decisions together.
 * BUT bottlenecks are not an individual behavior, they are a systemic
   structure, and so can be very hard to shift once set up.

We've heard a lot in our research about the position of bottlenecks and the
desire to escape that dynamic. But bottlenecks will appear in most if not all
networks. We can minimize them, and build around them, but we cannot avoid them
entirely. Anytime information asymmetry exists, it will create either power
imbalances (if information is hoarded) or bottleneck positions (as we strive to
share information) without mature distributed organizing structures in place. 

Rather than fight or deny these positions, we need to recognize them as a common
structural phase in networks. Then we can move from that hub-and-spoke phase
into sharing power. We can do this by encouraging the small group formation
which helps shift the flow of information and trust into a more appropriately
distributed structure. By paying attention to the systems that emerge from how
we work together, we gain the ability to choose better patterns.

Photo by Armand Khoury [https://unsplash.com/@armand_khoury] on Unsplash
[https://unsplash.com/photos/Ne7D-r77AYg]> We needed to slow things down
intentionally sometimes. We were moving at such a pace, with so many people,
that the bottleneck was intentionally created to make sure we could make
decisions about effectiveness and safety.... Then as we wanted to move faster,
as the context changed, we found those bottlenecks got in the way.

-Lauren Hebert
Clearing the way
How can we escape the dangers of bottlenecks?

 * Make sure that those in central positions are aware of the bottleneck traps.
 * Encourage new voices to reduce establishing invisible bias (we've all got
   it!).
 * Invite people into co-leadership, learning and use double linking whenever
   you can.

Power is a drug. The bottleneck position comes with headaches and busywork, but
it also comes with power. One of the things that emerged in this conversation
was the need for awareness, by anyone stepping into leadership, of the traps we
can too easily fall into when we hold positions of power. Coordinators must
remain aware of the fragility and danger to the existence of the network that
condensing power brings. If that stays top of mind, they continually practice
giving power to others. 

Ways our panel discussed to encourage this habit include double-linking
[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double_linking], co-leadership
[https://www.bridgespan.org/insights/how-to-make-co-leadership-work], and
patterns of learning and mentoring. Not only do these help with the bottleneck
problem, you get faster, better decisions when people work and learn together
regularly. When successful, power expands; the network, rather than a single
individual, gains the power to thrive. These conditions can create abundance for
far more people than otherwise would be available.

Model of Double Linking from A Practical Guide to Sociocracy 3.0
[https://patterns.sociocracy30.org/double-linking.html]> Bottlenecking is a system. That means its less of an individual issue or
failing of humans, and more about how we set up our orientation to the work, how
we structure working groups and the way we approach leadership in organizations.
Only a system can help fix the system.

-Jay Carmona
Warning signs
What signals or early warning signs hint at disengagement, and what actions can
coordinators take to address this?

 * People start to lose a sense that they can jump in and contribute
   meaningfully. 
 * Look for what's not there - things missing, or things all the same. 
 * Beware of metrics typically used to measure 'engagement'. They are not
   sensitive enough to sense the early stages of a disengaged group. 

We love (LOVE!) Jay's party analogies. Too often, studying relational dynamics
draw us into draws us into densely theoretical or heavy-handed efforts to create
connections. Jay reminds us that engagement - or sensing the lack of - is
something we humans do very naturally. Whether wallflowers, dancers, DJs, hosts,
or cooks, we're all social animals. If we tune into the feeling of a crowd in
this most human way, we can listen, feel, smell, and otherwise sense the vibe in
the room. Networks change; ebbs and flows are natural. To identify the dangers
of disengagement early, look for what's not there. You may see a lack of working
out loud, new people not joining or sticking around, people who all look or
sound the same, stalled progress or people claiming actions, lack of variety, or
even a lack of meaningful conflict. 

To convene a healthy network of humans, as with any fun party, hosts need to be
- or become - sensitive and kind enough to see, address, and shift things like
confusion, sadness, loneliness, fear. Be careful that you arent suppressing
this valuable feedback. You might proactively create ways to surface these
indicators. Tune into, or perhaps even invite 'meaningful conflict'. People who
care enough to disagree well can shape something that has purpose. Conveners
need to be frank with themselves and their active members when they sense
disengagement. They also need to be brave enough to do something about it, or
the network will fizzle out. Once people start walking out the door, it's likely
too late to do anything to restart the party.

Our panel party!> If youre at a party, what are the signs that people are bored
and going to leave? ...If everyone was sitting with a drink and staring back at
me - or, if everyone looks the same or acts the same - that's weird right? My
hair would stand up because it's not a normal human situation. The same thing
applies in digital communities.

-Jay Carmona
Healthy networked leadership
When people co-create a healthy network, what does leadership look like? How can
you prevent re-centralizing but lead enough to help the coordination?

 * Hierarchical structures have their own merits (nature is full of nested
   hierarchies) but people in central roles must also be aware of the traps.
   Centralizing power creates fragility, and unrestrained hierarchies can cause
   problems analogous to cancer.
 * Look for leaders willing to intentionally teach what they do, so that two
   people can now do that thing. This pairs well with co-leadership. 
 * Keep power explicit, but realize that healthy networked leadership structures
   are dynamic. Regularly check in with new members to understanding the
   experience of getting oriented in a changing environment. 

For healthy and effective networks to thrive, co-leadership is key. Too often,
when people try to build an equitable network, they want to share power with
everyone. This leads to a lack of clarity, even chaos, where nothing gets done.
In many networks, even if progress is made, too few people get credit. Work can
be invisible; or worse, credit claimed when unearned. Success goes not only to
the successful, but those willing to make themselves visible. The power of
networks can have a dark underbelly where the conveners or known figures get all
the acclaim, whether sought or not. 

Sharing power helps avoid these dark patterns. This does not mean a completely
flat structure; it can start with partnering with one person. Ask a board member
or CEO to mentor someone. Step into partnership with active community members
early and often. A model of co-leadership, as described above, can help this
happen. As you introduce co-leadership, be sure to pay attention to perspectives
from both the core team and the wider community. Do people with power in the
network recognize the traps? Do they help each other stay out of ruts and build
habits of offering power to others? Do community members have easy ways to give
feedback about what's not working well for them? Are they clear how to deepen
their involvement? Can they trust that their work will be recognized and valued?
When "Yes!" is the answer to these kinds of questions, networks find their tune,
and play 'in concert', like an orchestra being guided by the conductor and the
sheet music.

Photo by Photo by Manuel Ngeli [https://unsplash.com/@gwundrig] on Unsplash
[https://unsplash.com/photos/7CcPLtywRso]> If Im a leader at the top of a
hierarchy or bottleneck...[I need to notice if] for example, people stop talking
to me, or people are afraid of bringing up real tensions. [If so], my power and
habits are getting in the way. In some ways, the end result [of paying attention
to those dynamics] is decentralizing power or making it explicit.

-Carol Xu

posts.custom_excerpt: We recently hosted an insightful conversation with three amazing network coordinators: Jia (Carol) Xu, Ph.D, Jay Carmona, and Lauren Hebert. We discussed relational resilience, the dreaded bottleneck position, and the party-like feeling you find in a healthy, engaged network. Here are our takeaways.
